 A. BACKGROUND AND RECENT DEVELOPMIENTS 1. Repeated conflicts and their aftermaths. The Republic of Congo is emerging from a war with three rounds of violent conflicts between 1993 and 1999. At the height of the crisis in late 1999, approximately one-third of the Congolese population was displaced. Poverty, in both absolute and relative terms, is widespread. In 1994, unemployment was estimated to be close to 50 percent and remains at this level. Before the first civil war in 1993, an estimated 30 percent of the population of Brazzaville, which is generally better off than the rural population, lived on less than one UJS dollar a day. After three civil wars, the situation has deteriorated substantially in both urban and rural areas. After the recent conflict in 1999, approximately 70 percent of the population is estimated to be living below the poverty line. Per capita Gross National Product (GNP) in 1999 was estimated at US$670; while relatively high in comparison to most Sub- Saharan African countries, it disguised a highly skewed income distribution. For the majority of the Congolese population, the combined effects of civil war and neglect have been disastrous. 2. The Bank prepared a Transitional Support Strategy (TSS) for the Republic of Congo to guide operations over the coming two years. The TSS was discussed by the Board on January 16, 2001. The principal objective of the TSS is to support the Government by using a five- pronged approach: (i) strengthening economic stability and equitable growth and supporting reforms; (ii) reestablishing basic economic and social services; (iii) building capacity of government and civil society; (iv) fighting the growing threat of HIV/kIDS; and (v) providing assistance to war-affected and vulnerable population groups. B. IMPACT OF THE CONFLICT 3. Humanitarian plight. Whereas the wars of 1993/94 were essentially limited to Brazzaville, the 1997 and 1998/99 wars brought large-scale destruction to southern areas of the Republic of Congo, with the exception of the area around Pointe-Noire. This war created a humanitarian catastrophe with about 300,000 Brazzaville residents, representing almost 35 percent of the city's population, fleeing the capital and seeking refuge in forests where they lived under very difficult conditions for almost one year. At the height of the humanitarian crisis (in late 1999), an estimated 800,000 people, or almost one-third of the population of the Republic of Congo were displaced. Thirty thousand of ithese either sought refuge in Gabon or the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). Severity percent of those internally displaced were malnourished. Many lost all their belongings and suffered great physical and psychological hardships. The country was pillaged, (e.g., iron sheets were stolen from churches and houses, farms were burned, and health centers, schools and public buildings were looted). With the return of most displaced people, needs have shifted away from emergency humanitarian interventions toward social reintegration, infrastructure rehabilitation and reconstruction. 4. Economic Impact. The preliminary estimate of damage inflicted by the last two civil wars is approximately US$2.6 billion, well exceeding the size of the 1999 Gross Domestic Product (GDP). Non-oil GDP, a better indicator in assessing the impact of the war on domestic productive capacity (as oil is produced essentially offshore), declined by 19 percent between 1996 and 1999. By the time of the outbreak of the 1997 civil war, the Republic of Congo's
 economy had already been weakened by years of poor economic management and governance and by the bloody conflict of 1993/1994 and the resulting social unrest. It is estimated that 50 percent of agricultural tools were destroyed and 75 percent of livestock lost. Many archives were either destroyed or looted. The banking sector was strongly affected and commercial banks came out of the events insolvent and illiquid. Most deposits were de facto frozen and banks had no resources to contribute to rebuilding economic activity. 5. Macroeconomic Developments. Since independence, in 1960, the Republic of Congo has experienced ethnic strife, civil wars, institutional instability and poor governance. This has brought economic decline and the country's economic performance is well below its potential because of three decades of poor economic management, which was designed under a Marxist- oriented, single-party government. The GDP per capita declined by more than half, from US$1,300 in 1982 to US$630 in 2000. The GDP growth has been erratic; declining by 2.4 percent in 1997, rebounding by 3.7 percent in 1998, then again declining by 3.2 percent in 1999. After the 1999 cease-fire accord and successful implementation of the peace process, the GDP grew to 7.6 percent. Due to relatively higher oil prices, the fiscal balance moved from a deficit (-20 percent of GDP in 1998 and -6.2 percent in 1999) to a surplus in 2000 (1.2 percent of GDP) for the first time in several years. 6. The Government has taken emergency measures to boost the economy, including investing in post-war reconstruction efforts and resuming rail transportation service between Pointe-Noire and Brazzaville. As a result of these emergency measures, productive activities have resumed and annual inflation levels have remained marginal. 7. Social Indicators. Some social indicators have consistently declined over the years (but are no worse than indicators of other Sub-Saharan African countries). Gross primary school enrollment rates dropped from 125.2 percent in 1987 to 78.6 percent in 1998, while gross secondary enrollment rates dropped from about 70 percent in the early 1980s to 35.7 percent in 1998. As a result, literacy rates have also dropped from about 65 percent in the mid 1980s to 59.5 percent in 1998. The scarcity of qualified teachers, high student-teacher ratio, low-quality education and grade repeat-rates have been identified as the main weaknesses of the school system. The student-teacher ratio in Brazzaville is 80, compared to the established threshold of 60, which is the consequence of the limited number of classrooms and teachers. Twenty-eight school facilities have been rehabilitated, but 325 classrooms need to be rehabilitated or constructed. According to the Ministry of Education, 915 teachers in Brazzaville, representing 40 percent of all teachers in the city, are holding administrative positions instead of teaching. Parent-Teacher associations are very active in financing the maintenance of school facilities, including latrines, water points and electricity. 8. Most health indicators are still above the average of Sub-Saharan African standards because the country has enjoyed a higher GDP per capita than many countries on the African continent. Infant mortality is 81 per thousand, compared to an average of 106 per thousand elsewhere. Nevertheless, health services have declined steadily. Infant vaccination rates for measles have dropped from 99.4 percent in 1979 to 58 percent in 1999. Incidences of tuberculosis have almost quadrupled, from 32 per 100,000 in 1985 to 113 per 100,000 in 1999. IV/AIDS has become an increasing threat to the country's development outlook although sero prevalence in the general population is estimated at 7 percent. This figure is certainly 2
 underestimated, considering the total destruction of pre-war database, the poor reliability of the present database, and the lack of comprehensive epidemiological studies. A recent survey, conducted by the Ministry of Health, showed that 14.9 percent of pregnant women are infected with HIV/AIDS in Pointe-Noire and 5.5 percent in Brazzaville. Combined HIV/AIDS spread, violent deaths (due to repeated conflicts) and worsening health services have reduced life expectancy from 53 years in 1993 to 48.6 years in 1999. Life expectancy at birth in the Republic of Congo is now very close to the average in Sub-Sahara Africa, which contrasts with statistics of two decades ago when the country was among leading African countries in terms of longer life expectancy. 9. Institutional and Capacity Impact. The civil unrest and insecurity created by the conflicts have severely weakened Congo's institutional and human capacities. Disruption of the country's administrative capacity and institutional memory has been severe, with loss of manpower (particularly qualified staff), records, and Information Technology (IT) equipment for most institutions. Many professionals either left the country or were killed, thus leaving a vacuum in critical areas of service delivery, planning and management. Most public offices were burned down, destroyed, vandalized or pillaged in eight of the country's I I regions. Government vehicles were stolen as well as vehicles belonging to individuals and private institutions. 10. Road Infrastructure: The existing road network is in a poor state. The road network is composed of 1,875 km of national roads (11 percent), 3,574 km of secondary roads (21 percent), and 9,310 km of tertiary roads (53 percent). Only 7 percent of the country's road network is paved and paved stretches are scattered. Many regional capitals do not have reliable access roads. National and secondary roads are in disrepair as a result of years of insufficient maintenance aggravated by years of war. Secondary and agricultural feeder roads were already impassable before the war as maintenance was neglected during peacetime. The situation worsened during war times as bridges were destroyed for strategic reasons. Maintenance of roads was no more a priority and could not take place for security reasons and lack of funding since financial resources were diverted for military purposes and staff left their positions and hid in secluded areas. Existing equipment was looted and archives and technical documents were destroyed. It is not rare to spend over seven hours on an 80 km national road because of its state. Inaccessibility to the interior is due to lack of roads that strangles the rural sector and agriculture. The resulting high transport costs contribute to both rural and urban food insecurity. While roads crumble, reports of rotting food have been received. Many agricultural zones are inaccessible and their inhabitants remain isolated, thus making it impossible for them to market their produce 'and obtain necessary technical assistance to augment their agricultural production. 11. The urban road network in Brazzaville is estimated to include 200 km of asphalted roads and 530 km of dirt roads, according to information provided by the technical services of the City of Brazzaville. Asphalted roads are limited to the main roads, and the share of asphalted roads in comparison to the size of the city is quite limited. Seventy percent of asphalted roads are considered to be in a severe state of degradation and will need immediate and massive rehabilitation. Paved roads will be lost forever if rehabilitation does not take place in the near future. Many neighborhoods are inaccessible and public transportation is no more available in those areas and the population has to walk over long distances to reach their houses. 3
 12. Railway infrastructure. Adequate transport between the seaport of Pointe-Noire and Brazzaville is critical for the Republic of Congo's economy, as well as for land-locked Central African Republic and Chad. The railway line between Pointe-Noire and Brazzaville is presently, and will remain in coming years, the only high capacity, all weather, transport mode on this route. Railway infrastructure and service facilities were damaged during the civil war. The railway line between Pointe-Noire and Brazzaville, the econornic umbilical cord of the country, was destroyed at several points. Rail and road traffic were interrupted in September 1996 and resumed only in July 2000, after reconstruction of bridges destroyed during the war. At present, transport capacity is severely constrained by inadequate locomotive power, and train movement safety is at risk due to a poor telecommunication system and damaged railway tracks in some areas of a major tunnel. Accidents on the railway line, apart from the human toll, had dramatic impacts on the economy. After the last derailment of October 2001, the city of Brazzaville almost completely stopped functioning as the supply of gasoline was interrupted for two days. Cab drivers had to wait at gas stations all night so as to ensure the purchase of fuel in the morning and car queues at gas stations reached 300 to 400 meters. 13. Drainage. Brazzaville is traversed by many perennial streams, such as Djiri, Kelekele, Mikalu, Tsieme, M'Foa, M'Filou and Djoue all flowing into the Congo River. The primary drainage system is principally made up of gutters, drains and streams that join the Congo River, which flows from east to west. This drainage system, built during the colonial period, has severely degraded, partly because of the wars and partly because of the lack of appropriate maintenance, which can also be attributed to the war situation. This system, according to the technical services of the City of Brazzaville, comprises about 410 kilometers of secondary drains and 10 kilometers of primary drains. The drainage network is unevenly distributed in Brazzaville and older sections of the city barely have basic drainage infrastructure. The little that exists is mainly concentrated in primary roads, and most secondary road networks are not drained. The primary drainage system and streams are hampered by a high level of silt and rapidly growing aquatic plants, which result in frequent flooding during heavy rainfalls. In addition, the limited hydraulic capacity of the drains and increased soil impermeability has led to frequent flooding of the busiest sections of the city. 14. Due to the lack of sufficient drainage facilities and the poor quality of soils in areas with high slopes, most of the southern districts of the city experienced severe soil erosion that has destroyed many houses in recent years. Erosion represents a large threat to buildings, roads and the water distribution network. 15. Water. In Congo, having reliable access to water depends largely upon whether you live in an urban or rural area. The high urbanization rate favored public financing of water to urban centers. Water is delivered to urban centers by Soci6te Nationale de Distribution d'Eau (SNDE), which is a national public corporation. Thirty six percent of the population is connected to the water supply network, while the remaining population relies on water sold by neighboring households connected to the network, or from other unsafe water sources. Access to water services was estimated to be around 50 percent in urban areas in 1998. Recent figures showed that only 11 percent of the rural population has access to adequate water supply and most of the population relies on water of dubious quality from streams and rivers. Despite favorable hydrological conditions (with many high flows, perennial rivers and streams), only 46 percent of 4
 the country's population has access to reliable quality water. This figure is below the average Sub-Saharan Africa standard of 55 percent. 16. Sanitation. In 1996, a survey conducted in Brazzaville by the Ministry of Health found that 15 percent of households had septic tanks, 23 percent had water closets, 42 percent had traditional latrines, and 15 percent did not have toilet facilities and used neighbors' or nearby clearings as toilets. Brazzaville has only three solid waste collection trucks, even though the need is three to four times greater; therefore, available waste collection trucks cannot meet the demand. This has resulted in poor solid waste collection with large quantities of domestic waste being dumped into ditches, thus blocking streams and drains and further complicating the drainage issue. Inappropriate excreta and sludge removal arrangements, as well as discharge of wastewater in open spaces and drains compound this situation. Also, inappropriate disposal of sewage and wastewater leads to pools of polluted water, which conveys hydro fecal related diseases and provides breeding grounds for mosquitoes, especially in densely populated neighborhoods, such as Poto Poto, Ouenze, Moungali and Talangai. C. GOVERNMENT RESPONSE 17. In response to the crisis, the Government has prepared, in a participatory way with representatives from the local NGO community, a three-year Interim Post-Conflict Program ("Programme Interimaire Post-Conflit") for the period 2000-02, which aims at helping the Republic of Congo move from a humanitarian crisis to a sustainable economic and social development, and from a state-dominated to a market-based economy. Sectoral strategies were prepared for basic sectors (energy, road and railway infrastructure, telecommunications); support sectors (agriculture and livestock, forestry, petroleum, tourism, environnment and mines); social sectors (health, water, sanitation and drainage, education, youth, shelter); and the private sector (small- and medium-scale enterprises, trade, handicraft, informal economy). The donor community reviewed the proposed program, for which the Government seeks donor support, during a multi-donor mission to Brazzaville in April 2000. The program has two major elements: emergency and growth. 18. Emergency. With the signing of agreements with key military commanders of the main fighting groups to cease fire and end hostilities, the security situation has improved significantly in Brazzaville and throughout the entire country. The devastation of the economy and infrastructure assets is huge. Restoring the economy and rebuilding the dilapidated infrastructure are enormous challenges for the Government, while public finances are still in a weak condition. Rebuilding infrastructure, bringing the administration and its staff back and rebuilding their capacity, paying the salaries of civil servants, increasing public revenues, creating job opportunities for unemployed youth, demobi]lizing and reinserting former militiamen, strengthening the economy and coordinating with donors are all priority actions facing the Government. Support from donors has been very limited and concentrated on humanitarian needs, leaving almost all the burden of rehabilitating the infrastructure and rebuilding the economy to the Government. One of the main issues faced by the Government is defining its priorities and drawing support, on a coordinated basis, from its external partners. The Government seeks to improve access to the country's interior and provide basic road infrastructure, health, education, and improve sanitary conditions for the urban population. It 5
 aims at ensuring the free circulation of persons and transfer of goods through improved Government maintained security, effective road infrastructure and resumption of railway service between Pointe-Noire and Brazzaville, which is vital for jump-starting economic activities in Brazzaville and the country. Rehabilitation of dilapidated roads in Brazzaville and rural areas is a key objective, as is the demobilization and reintegration of ex-militias in an impartial, equitable and balanced manner, and providing short-term employment to demobilized combatants and youths. In order to improve food security, the relaunching of agricultural and livestock activities, including agro-industry, is another priority. 19. Growth. The relaunching of the productive sector is an essential component toward poverty reduction and econornic and sustainable development. Support to the private sector and diversification of the economy are central elements thereof, fighting unemployment another. The program includes efforts aimed at increasing competitiveness through, among others, progressive elimination of non-tariff barriers and modernization of the labor law. The Government further intends to deepen subregional integration, through improvements in the transport infrastructure, which will stimulate the exchange of goods and services. Reinforcement of administrative and institutional capacities of the State and strengthening the rule of law are considered important elements to overcoming dysfunctional economic and financial management processes. 20. Rehabilitation activities performed. The Government has financed (out of its own modest resources) quite a large capital investment program to rehabilitate the railway line between Pointe-Noire and Brazzaville (mostly the bridges). Railway traffic, which stopped for more than a year following the 1999 war, resumed in August 2000. After the recent war, some of the water production capacity and distribution system have been reestablished in Brazzaville. The Government, supported by different NGOs and with its own resources, has reestablished water production and distribution by rehabilitating some electric transformers to run treatment plants and boreholes, and has purchased limited chemical products for water treatment. The Government has also financed partial rehabilitation of devastated office buildings and equipment in order to resume activities in the administration. Many schools and health centers were rehabilitated in Brazzaville and in rural areas. The Government has embarked on a limited road rehabilitation program in Brazzaville aimed at easing transportation in the capital city. Main electricity production centers and their supporting infrastructure were rehabilitated, but are still inadequate in coping with demand. Even with those efforts, a lot remains to be done to bring infrastructure services back to pre-war level. Growing demand from inhabitants and resumption of economic activities are far from being satisfied. Significant financial resources will be needed to rebuild destroyed and dilapidated infrastructure and donors' resources, as well as private sector financing will be required to complement the Government's limited financial means. 21. Structural reforms, Governance and Transparency. To lay the foundation for higher and sustainable growth in years to come and under a market-based economy, Congolese authorities have engaged in full-fledged privatization efforts of the three commercial banks, key public utilities (water, electricity and telecommunications), railway operations and oil products distribution. The government is currently pursuing options to privatize the railway through a concession, and has recruited a consulting firm to provide support to the Privatization Committee. A comprehensive rehabilitation program for infrastructure and equipment will be implemented as part of the concession and according to the bidding documents. The concessionaire, who will also be responsible for putting together the needed funds, will design 6
 this program in order to meet its performance obligations spelled out in the concession contract to be signed between the operator and the Republic of Congo. However, the benefits of this program are not expected to materialize before 2005. Bids for the selection of operators and concessionaires have been sent out. Related investments to increase capacity and manage the sectors will be left to the private sector. The Government is also engaged in improving governance and increasing transparency, by strengthening the overall budget performance and tracking the use of revenues generated by the oil sector. A framework agreement, clarifying the financial relationships between Societe Nationale des Petroles du Congo (SNPC) and the State (oil revenues represented 78 percent of Government revenues in 2000), was signed on June 29, 2001. Other actions the Government will carry out include regular audits of SNPC, public funds managed by public institutions, logging permits, and review of the national procurement code. D. INTERNATIONAL RESPONSE 22. Donors have shown support to the Republic of Congo's Government in its rehabilitation, recovery, peace and national reconciliation process. In this context, UNDP and UN OCHA organized a humanitarian donors' meeting and consolidated appeal in Geneva in July 2001. Eleven UN agencies are in the country and actively involved in various areas, e.g., revival of productive activities, emergency needs, reestablishing basic social services and infrastructure, and promoting democracy and human rights. UNDP launched an Arms Collecting and Reintegration Program, under the implementation of IOM and financed by a Post Conflict Grant provided by the World Bank. After six months of operation, this program has reintegrated 3,400 ex-combatants. UNDP and IOM aim at reaching about 12,000 more ex-combatants within the next 12 months when the program ends. France, the United States, and Italy, are actively involved in diverse social and humanitarian activities. Resources of the 6t, 7th and 8th European funds are still available, and the European Union (EU) has allocated 43 million Euros to the country under the 8th European Fund. AfDB is maintaining dialogue with the Republic of Congo while at the same time reviewing its reengagement strategy in the country with respect to the clearance of arrears due to this institution. 23. Response on the Infrastructure Sectors. The EU has been very active in the country since the end of the last conflict. It has financed US$5 million in urban and rural infrastructure rehabilitation projects, urban sanitation and solid waste management activities. The EU is financing feasibility and detailed technical studies for the reconstruction of the road between Brazzaville, Kinkala and Matoumbou, and intends to finance the construction of this road. The EU has already financed rehabilitation of the Avenue de la Tsieme and the Ceinture maraichaire in Brazzaville, the road between Kinkala and Boko and the cleaning of drainage facilities in Brazzaville and Pointe-Noire by using remaining funds from previous aid packages not fully disbursed. The EU approved the 8th European Development Fund package of 43 million Euros to the Government on May 17, 2001. The bulk of this aid package (66 percent) will finance construction of the road between Brazzaville and Kinkala, about 250 km rural roads rehabilitation works in the northern, central and southern areas of the country and the national transportation plan. The EU may also finance construction of the connection road between the southern exit of the city of Brazzaville and the hinterland. The 9th European Development Fund, 7
 a total amount of 117 million Euros, is being discussed and will be used to finance roads in addition to support democracy, human rights and state of law. 24. The French Development Agency had intended to finance different projects; these include rehabilitation of the roads connecting Kinkala to Loutete; an Urban Rehabilitation project for Brazzaville and Pointe-Noire, including drainage and road rehabilitation works and municipal capacity building for US$18 million; and an employment and reinsertion project in the same cities, including a labor-intensive works component for US$5 million. Detailed design studies for the Urban Rehabilitation project and preliminary studies for the Employment and Reinsertion Project have been prepared and are available. These projects cannot be implemented because the Republic of Congo is in a non-accrual status regarding its debt arrears with AFD. The agency is financing studies to define rehabilitation works to be carried out on the Port of Pointe-Noire, and the privatization scheme for the Port of Brazzaville and secondary ports with remaining funds from previous structural adjustment programs. In the meantime, AFD financed, on an account sharing arrangement with IDA, feasibility and preliminary studies on roads, drainage works and capacity building activities. These studies are available and have been used to define and cost components of the proposed project. 25. The French Ministry of Cooperation has been active in the country since 1999 and support programs related to school rehabilitation, teacher training and health sector technical assistance. The French ministry is preparing a new assistance program aimed at strengthening Brazzaville and Pointe-Noire municipalities. 26. In 1998, the African Development Bank prepared a US$10 million emergency recovery credit, with particular focus on infrastructure rehabilitation, aimed at improving drainage and roads in Poto Poto and Ouenze districts in Brazzaville while using, whenever possible, labor- intensive methods, rehabilitation of school facilities, microfinance and capacity building activities. AfDB could not continue this operation because the Republic of Congo has not cleared its arrears with AfDB. E. IDA RESPONSE AND STRATEGY I. Elements of IDA Response 27. The proposed Emergency Infrastructure Rehabilitation and Living Conditions Improvement Project is an integral part of the Bank's Transitional Support Strategy and will address unemployment issues through labor-intensive projects, infrastructure rehabilitation to assist the Republic of Congo in the transition from war to sustainable peace, and the resumption of economic and social development. The TSS guides the Bank's engagement over the next 24- months in support of the Government's Interim Post Conflict Program, in areas where the Bank has a clear comparative advantage. The principal objective of the Bank's TSS is to support the Government in facing the four simultaneous challenges of consolidating its home-grown peace process: laying and solidifying the foundation for the democratization of political life, physically reconstructing the country, improving economic management through increased transparency and good governance in public resource management. Achievement of this objective will be based on: 8
 a) Strengthening economic stability and equitable growth and supporting reforms to facilitate the transition to a market-based economy; this would be closely linked with the IMF program; b) Reestablishing basic economic and social services, including rehabilitation and maintenance of small- and large-scale infrastructure; c) Building capacity of government and civil society so as to help the Republic of Congo face the challenges of designing and implementing effective programs, improve governance, and undertake public transactions transparently; d) Fighting the growing threat of HIV/AIDS; and e) Providing assistance to war-affected and vulnerable population groups. 28. There are five projects being prepared under the strategy. The proposed project is the fourth operation of the TSS. It would respond to the emergency of reestablishing basic economic and social services, rehabilitating and maintaining small- and large-scale social infrastructures to help jump-start the economy. This will be achieved by rehabilitating the railways infrastructure, improving sanitary conditions in the Brazzaville neighborhoods, facilitating transportation in Brazzaville while reestablishing connections between the rural areas and the cities, and providing job opportunities for the urban youth. 29. Other operations under the Bank's Transitional Support Strategy include: (i) a US$37.5 million Post Conflict ERC, approved by the Bank's Board of Directors on July 31, 2001, following the implementation of structural reforms to strengthen economic stability, expand the private sector's role by privatizing all commercial banks, forestry companies, key public utilities and increase transparency in the use of oil revenues; (ii) a US$5 million Emergency Demobilization, Disarmament and Reintegration Credit (Cr 3561 COB), approved on July 31, 2001, aimed at providing sound post-conflict reintegration options to currently unemployed ex- combatants and rehabilitating physical and social infrastructures in their original communities; (iii) a US$7 rnillion Transparency and Governance Capacity Building Project, approved on February 7, 2002, to accompany reforms envisaged under the Post-Conflict Economic Rehabilitation Credit (Post Conflict ERC), and to enhance transparency of decision making in the oil and gas sectors, in public finance, particularly the Ministry of Economy, Finance and Budget (MoFFB), and in government's disengagement from the productive sectors of the economy, focusing on the privatization program; and (iv) an HIV/AIDS project to address the growing threat of AIDS. 30. The Bank is also in the process of engaging in non-lending activities. These activities will include public expenditure reviews, a social assessment, a labor market analysis and studies on natural resources management. The public expenditure reviews will aim at rationalizing revenues and expenditures and make the budgetary process and management of public resources more transparent and more effective to the country's development objectives. Given the huge unemployment situation facing the country, a better knowledge of the labor market is key to developing strategies and approaches to facilitate and increase employment opportunities. The Bank has, through a US$1 million Post-Conflict grant and a US$0.5 million Institutional Development Grant, supported activities related to promotion of youth and women, and studies 9
 aimed at defining an enabling environment for private sector participation in the telecommunications sector. II. Rationale for IDA Involvement 31. The proposed Emergency Reconstruction, Rehabilitation and Living Conditions Improvement Project will help address the country's immediate rehabilitation needs. The rebuilding of basic and social infrastructure, using labor-intensive methods, will help create jobs. The Bank chaired the Donors' consultation, held in Paris in October 2000, and was asked to lead the donor community by providing a framework for mobilizing donor resources, strengthening the Government's aid coordination capacity and sharing its post-conflict experience. During the Paris meeting, it was stressed that support from the international community may help avert the creation of a lost generation of uneducated youth with a bleak future, who could be a danger to the society in the future as the social systems further fall into disarray. Finally, the Bank has also developed valuable experience in implementing labor-intensive public works. III. Lessons Learned 32. Previous and current Bank operations on emergency reconstruction in post-conflict countries (Ethiopia, Eritrea, Rwanda, Uganda, Bosnia-Herzegovina) have provided us with valuable lessons, which have been included in the design of this project. One lesson is to establish dialogue on a wide range of technical issues, implementation arrangements and management decisions. This has been achieved by assessing the potential for saving by using local materials. The Government has agreed to include local materials for the construction of tertiary roads and drainage networks and to use labor-intensive methods for infrastructure works. The municipality of Brazzaville has also agreed to move away from its traditional approach and to contract out operation and maintenance of urban roads and drainage facilities to the local private sector and earmark appropriate funds for maintenance purposes. 33. Another lesson is that implementation arrangements should be kept simple to accommodate limited capacity and avoid unrealistic expectations because the process of rehabilitation is lengthy and complex. Including too many components and too many activities in such a project can create excessive complexity that can be detrimental to project objectives. Even if the project is relatively large, project interventions are limited in comparison to the needs identified in the Government Emergency Reconstruction Program presented to the donor community. Activities related to water supply, electricity and telecommunications, which are very important, are not part of the project. Even if commitment is high, and when capacity is low, (which is normally the case in post-conflict situation), project designs should remain relatively simple while additional capacity should be ensured through continued technical assistance and training of project staff. Even if the number of stakeholders involved in the project is quite important, implementation will lie with only one unit. 34. A third lesson is that procurement and disbursement procedures should be kept in line with the post-conflict context. In order to speed up disbursement, streamlined and expeditious procurement arrangements should be used to avoid late delivery of goods and commissioning of work. The project has embraced this lesson and procurement procedures under the project will not follow national regulations, which are known to be cumbersome, unclear and lengthy. Contract signing responsibilities have been limited to the project coordinator. 10

Project Objective 36. The objective of the Emergency Infrastructure Rehabilitation and Living Conditions Improvement Project is to contribute to reestablishment of basic economic activities and social services by rehabilitating primary, secondary and urban roads, railways, drainage, and school facilities. 37. This decision is particularly sensitive and will expedite procurement processes. H. BENEFITS AND RISKS I. Benefits 64. Potential benefits of support to the Republic of Congo in the form of the proposed Project largely outweigh the risks. By focusing its financing priority areas (e.g. infrastructure, such as roads and railways, social infrastructure and private sector rehabilitation), the project will eventually jump-start the economy and create conditions for long-term development, while at the same time tackling immediate economic and social needs of the most vulnerable people by creating employment. Reestablishing a well functioning railway system between Pointe-Noire (the port and the oil producing center) and Brazzaville is paramount to any economic development and industrial activity in Brazzaville and in the country. In addition, a well functioning railway system will increase availability of petroleum products to the Central African Republic (CAR), and help reduce erratic variations of gasoline price and repeated shortages of petroleum products in this country. Spill over effects will help create a more stable economic and political environment in CAR, in particular, and security in Congo and in the region as a whole. More specifically, the project will benefit local entrepreneurs and national consulting firms, and improve living conditions in densely populated districts of Brazzaville and in the regions. Benefits encompassing the Republic of Congo (and spread over the region) are expected from the project because greater stability and peace in the Republic of Congo, as a consequence of the project, will constitute a good example to follow for countries embattled in conflicts in the troubled Central and Great Lakes region. II. Risks and Mitigation Measures 65. In light of the Republic of Congo's fragile political situation and its relatively weak implementation capacity, the proposed credit is at considerable risk. The first risk is political and social, and can be associated with the failure of the transition process to democracy and to building a political system that would resolve differences without recourse to violence. Such failure could lead to renewed conflict, destruction of rebuilt infrastructure and slippage in project implementation. Faced with continued political and social instability, the Government's determination to sustain implementation of emergency rehabilitation may be questioned. The national dialogue on a new constitution and the convention for peace and national reconciliation, 19
 held in April 2001, provides reassurances and illustrates the Government's commitment to building a stable and peaceful political system. A constitution was approved on January 20, 2002, and Presidential elections took place on March 10, 2002. 66. The second risk is the weak institutional and administrative capacity that could lead to delays in project implementation. To mitigate this risk, the proposed Project would use (i) simplified implementation arrangements to accommodate the limited capacity with only one PIU, staffed with personnel selected on a competitive basis and assisted by short-term technical assistance; and (ii) streamlined procurement processes by giving full responsibility to the PIU and up front adoption of standard bidding documents. A third risk is linked to the difficulty of the Government to service its debt with the Bank on time and the suspension of disbursements for the project. Support provided by the Bank through future Public Expenditure Reviews and increased transparency in the collection and use of national resources that is foreseen from the implementation of the Transparency and Government Project financed by the Bank, will help mitigate this risk. 67. While the risks are considerable in the Republic of Congo, the cost of no support from the international community would exacerbate the violence, which has been under control since the end of 1999. A lack of support from the international community would also create a lost generation of uneducated youth who could be a danger to the society in years to come, as social systems further fall into disarray. Uncontrolled violence and continued instability in the Republic of Congo would also have severe implications for peace in the delicate Great Lakes region and the entire Central Africa. 20

The country's procurement procedures do not conflict with Bank Guidelines. The Country's Procurement capacity has been weakened substantially following the civil war in 1997. 1.2. Substantial capacity rebuilding will be needed to recreate procurement proficiency at the central and sector levels. It is anticipated that during the Transparency and Governance Capacity Building Project (TGCBP), capacity of the public procurement system will be assessed and an action plan prepared to develop a training program to strengthen capacity and help reduce the procurement risk level for Government and future IDA-financed investments. In 1982, a legal text created a procurement committee (Commission Nationale des Marches) under the responsibility of the Presidency and chaired by a representative of the MEFB. 1.3. Several Committee members are reportedly not familiar with Bank guidelines and procedures on procurement and disbursement. Since Committee members will not be involved in the project as TGCB project will help build the required capacity. Procurement Capacity Assessment of the PIU 1.9 An assessment of PIU's capacity to implement project procureiment in accordance with the criteria outlined in Annex 3 of LACI Implementation Hand Book was completed (detailed report is in the project files). The review assessed the risks (institutional, procedural) that may negatively affect the ability of the PIU to carry out procurement activities. The risks identified in the assessment are the following: (i) abusive use of sole source/direct contracting; (ii) inadequate submission period for bids; (iii) lack of sufficiently qualified procurement specialists in the country; (iv) lack of training of staff handling procurement matters; (v) long contract signing delays; and (vi) inconsistency of the country 29

This has led, among other factors, to slower disbursements, in some cases to misuse of funds. In addition, the economic and political atmosphere in the country, in which the law operates, is not conducive to fair and transparent procurement processes. Therefore, the Republic of Congo appears as a "high risk" country from a procurement point of view. 1.10 The prior review thresholds recommended are those applicable to a "high risk" country. doc.abstracts: The objective of the Emergency Reconstruction, Rehabilitation and Living Conditions Improvement Project in Congo, is to contribute to the re-establishment of basic economic activities, and social services, by rehabilitating primary, secondary, and urban roads, drainage and school facilities. By prioritizing areas in infrastructure, such as roads, social infrastructure and private sector rehabilitation, the credit will benefit the jump-start of the economy, and create conditions for long-term development, while tackling immediate economic and social needs of the most vulnerable, i.e., employment creation. Specifically, the project will benefit local entrepreneurs, and national consulting firms, and improve living conditions. Nonetheless, political and social risks, associated with the failure of the transition process to democracy, and to building a political system that will resolve differences without recourse to violence, may hinder success, in addition to weak institutional, and administrative capacities, and the Government's inability to service its debt with the Bank. However, the project will use simplified implementation arrangements, and streamline procurement processes, as well as provide support to the upcoming Public Expenditures Review, to mitigate risks.
